bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Mrs. George Carroll, October 26, 1954

div1.p: Hench wants to meet Mrs. Carroll and show her photographs of the dedication of Camp Lazear. He also would like to make copies of some of James Carroll's manuscripts.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Mrs. George Carroll, October 26, 1954
div1.p:
October 26, 1954 Mrs. George S. H. Carroll
2814 Rhode Island Avenue, N.E.
Washington, D. C.
My dear Mrs. Carroll:

I must attend medical meetings in Philadelphia on Saturday and Sunday,
November 13 and 14 and must attend a committee meeting in Washington on
November 12, probably in the morning, which would take about two hours.

I do hope that you will be home on November 12. I should like very much
to do two things. First of all, I would like to bring my kodachromes of
Camp Lazear and spend a half hour showing you these lovely colored pictures
of the dedication of Camp Lazear and the honors to Doctor Carroll with
photographs of his bronze plaque and so on. Secondly, I would like in
particular to do this time what you very graciously said you would let me
do the next time I came to Washington. Namely, that you and I would take
just a few of the manuscripts that we laid aside in that small special
package down to a photostat company and have them quickly copied. You and
I can go together, perhaps Friday afternoon by taxi, to the company, stay
with them for the half hour or so that it would require and then take the
manuscripts right back to your house. I was so pleased when you told me
last time that you had no objection to my doing this and I was so glad
that your lawyer of the firm of Leckie and Sherier agreed that it was
appropriate for you to let me do this.

I hope you received the letter I send you some time ago about your arthritis
and I should be glad to talk to you about this further. Indeed, if you
want me to do so, I can talk to Doctor Gibson. He very kindly wrote me in
answer to my letter about you. He is very anxious to help you in any way
possible and to cooperate with me or anyone else who might help you.

As you of course suggested, I have not written to your sisters-in-law
yet or discussed with them in any way the material in your possession.
For your convenience, I enclose a stamped envelope and a little memoran-
dum which you can just check. I do hope this date is agreeable to you
as it will be impossible for me to get to Washington again this year and
of course I shall bring back to you the two or three photographs which you
kindly loaned to me and which I have hesitated in consigning to the regular
mail.

Sincerely yours,
P. S. Hench, M.D.
PSH:alc
Enclosure
P.S.: I have again written Doctor Gibson to see if there is any way in
which we can assist you in getting full information about possible surgery.
I have not contacted your lawyer, the one to whom I talked on the phone
with your permission. I am sure that you will be gracious enough to let me
copy the yellow fever data as you and your lawyer promised I could without
any further prodding from him. As you say, if I wrote to him he might contact
you and use that as an excuse to send you another bill.

1. I can meet you Friday, November 12, presumably in the afternoon and
go with you to a downtown photostat company.
2. I understand that you are picking the name of a downtown photostat
company to do this photostating and will go there with you.
3. (Alternate to No. 2): If you have not made final arrangements with
any photostat company, I suggest the ______________________ Company which
I know about and which is recommended to me by my lawyer.
